thread.title: Kara and Michael's reunion sets sail in Anything Goes
thread.title_full: Kara and Michael's reunion sets sail in Anything Goes

title: Kara and Michael's reunion sets sail in Anything Goes
text:
Kara and Michael's reunion sets sail in Anything Goes Michelle Gately | 15th Oct 2015 9:43 AM Michelle Gately DE-LOVELY: Kara Lane and Michael Robertson will hit the Pilbeam Theatre stage as Reno Sweeny and Billy Crocker for Anything Goes at the end of the month. Tracey Hamlyn Local Real Estate Cars For Sale 
SITTING in a theatre, watching 42nd Street play out on stage, was the moment Michael Robertson and Kara Lane decided performing was going to be their life. 
Growing up as part of Rockhampton's performing arts and eisteddfod community, the pair knew of each other long before they worked together. 
As a teenager, Michael watched Kara Lane perform the role of Hope Harcourt in Rockhampton High School's production of Anything Goes. 
In a few weeks, the pair will be reunited on stage in the same production. 
When the SS American sails into the Pilbeam Theatre, Kara and Michael will take to the stage as Reno Sweeny and Billy Crocker in the de-lovely Cole Porter musical. 
But they're not the only ones reunited for the production. 
Kara grew up in the Rockhampton Musical Union Choir hall, with her mother, singing teacher Christine Netherwood, playing many a lead role. 
Her brothers, Dean and Travis Netherwood, are also part of the Anything Goes team on stage and behind the scenes. Anything goes: Musical theatre star Kara Lane arrives home for Rockhampton Musical Union's October production, Anything Goes. 
Production choreographer Jan Kennedy this year had a helping hand from daughter Liz Perez, who grew up and studied with Kara, while she was home on holiday from America. 
The show's stage manager, Suzanne Galletly, is the daughter of director Pat McKenna and danced at the same ballet academy as Kara. 
Michael said it had been a pleasure to work with Kara again, both bouncing off each other to bring more to their roles. 
"One of us makes a mistake and you don't really notice it because we both cover it up," Michael said. 
"I think now we're doing runs of the show it's good ... it's really starting to fall together now. 
"That's when the magic happens, when all the little bits fall together." Michael Robertson and Kara Lane perform an item from Oliver! in the RMU Choir's presentation of Stage Stunners 2012. Photo contributed. Photo contributed ROK141015perfo 
Although Kara also took to the stage as Reno at Kilworth House Theatre in the UK, she described this production as "completely different" in many ways. 
"I may be singing the songs the same way, I may be saying some of the lines with the same intonation, but the majority of the show, the intention and everything I say, comes out with a different meaning," Kara said. 
"You bounce of different people. 
"It's not about being on stage and just showing what you can do, it's about team work and reacting to what other people give you." 
Returning to play Reno was something Kara said she had "wanted to do it for a very long time". 
"I can't even pinpoint why exactly," she said. 
"It's not something I wanted to do to come home and show off or anything. 
"In fact, my ultimate goal for the end of this show is for people who have watched in the auditorium to come up to other people in the cast and go 'everyone stood out in that show'. 
"I'd almost be really flattered if someone went 'I really thought (Kara Lane) would stand out more'. 
"I want the show to be an amazing show and I want everyone (in the cast) to go away from it feeling they've learnt something that can bring some more knowledge to the next show they do." 
IF YOU GO 
Friday, October 30 and Saturday, October 31 from 7.30pm 
Sunday, November 1 from 1.30pm 
Tickets available at the Pilbeam Theatre box office, at seeitlive.com.au or through 49274111 anything goes
